questions.statement: An electromagnet is a type of magnet in which magnetic field is produced through electric current.
questions.explanation: This is the definition of an electromagnet as stated in the text.

questions.statement: The core of an electromagnet is made of hard steel.
questions.explanation: The core of an electromagnet is made of soft iron, not hard steel.

questions.statement: An electromagnet retains its magnetism even after the current is switched off.
questions.explanation: An electromagnet loses its magnetism as soon as the current is stopped.

questions.statement: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet.
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet which retains magnetism only when electric current passes through it.

questions.statement: Permanent magnets are usually made of soft materials.
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets are usually made of hard materials, not soft materials.

questions.statement: Bar magnets and horse-shoe magnets are examples of permanent magnets.
questions.explanation: Examples of permanent magnets are bar magnets and horse-shoe magnets.

questions.statement: Electromagnets can only be bar-shaped.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are of two types based on shape - bar-shaped and U-shaped.

questions.statement: The end of an electromagnet where current flows clockwise acts as the north pole.
questions.explanation: The end where current flows clockwise acts as the south pole, not north pole.

questions.statement: The end of an electromagnet where current flows anticlockwise acts as the north pole.
questions.explanation: The end where current flows anticlockwise acts as the north pole.

questions.statement: Bare copper wire is used in making electromagnets.
questions.explanation: Insulated copper wire is used, not bare copper wire.

questions.statement: An iron nail can be converted into an electromagnet by passing current through a coil wound around it.
questions.explanation: An iron nail gets converted into an electromagnet when current flows through the coil wound around it.

questions.statement: The strength of an electromagnet decreases when the current flowing through it increases.
questions.explanation: The strength increases when current increases. They are directly proportional.

questions.statement: Increasing the number of turns of the coil increases the strength of an electromagnet.
questions.explanation: On increasing the number of turns of the coil, the strength of the electromagnet can be increased.

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used in bullet trains.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in bullet trains.

questions.statement: Electromagnets cannot be used to lift heavy loads.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in cranes to lift heavy loads of scrap iron and steel.

questions.statement: An electric bell uses an electromagnet.
questions.explanation: An electric bell is a useful application of an electromagnet.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: The armature in an electric bell is made of copper.
questions.explanation: The armature is made of iron, not copper.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: In an electric bell, the hammer hits the gong to produce sound.
questions.explanation: The hammer attached to the armature hits the gong and sound is produced.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: The spring in an electric bell pushes the armature away.
questions.explanation: The spring pulls the armature back to its original position.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Electromagnetic induction produces induced current.
questions.explanation: The current produced by electromagnetic induction is called induced current.

questions.statement: An electric current can produce a magnetic field.
questions.explanation: An electric current produces a magnetic field - this is the basis of electromagnetism.

questions.statement: A magnetic field can produce an electric current.
questions.explanation: An electric current can be produced from a magnetic field through electromagnetic induction.

questions.statement: We can get a magnet with a single pole.
questions.explanation: This is a myth. All magnets have two poles even if one is covered or hidden.

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used in audio and video tapes.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in audio and video tapes.

questions.statement: Electromagnets can be used to remove steel splinters from wounds.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used for removing steel splinters from patient's wounds.

questions.statement: Temporary magnets retain their magnetic properties without external magnetic field.
questions.explanation: Temporary magnets behave as magnets only in the presence of a strong magnetic field.

questions.statement: The components of an electric bell are fitted on a metal board.
questions.explanation: The components are fitted on a flat wooden or plastic board, not metal.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: When the push button of an electric bell is released, the bell stops ringing.
questions.explanation: The bell rings only as long as the push button switch is kept pressed.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used in the preparation of permanent magnets.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in preparation of permanent magnets.

questions.statement: The strength of an electromagnet is inversely proportional to the current flowing through it.
questions.explanation: The strength is directly proportional to the current, not inversely proportional.

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used for separation of iron ore from its impurities.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used for separation of iron ore and its impurities.

questions.statement: In an electric bell, the electromagnet attracts the armature when current flows.
questions.explanation: When current flows, the electromagnet gets magnetised and attracts the armature made of iron.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: The circuit in an electric bell breaks when the armature touches the contact screw.
questions.explanation: The circuit breaks when the armature loses contact with the contact screw due to displacement.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used in electric motors.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in electrical appliances such as telephones, electric motors and electric bells.

questions.statement: A U-shaped electromagnet has copper wire wrapped around a U-shaped soft iron core.
questions.explanation: In U-shaped electromagnet, insulated copper wire is wrapped around a U-shaped soft iron core.

questions.statement: Electromagnetic induction requires a constant magnetic field.
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic induction occurs due to change in magnetic lines of force, not constant field.

questions.statement: Paper clips are attracted to the ends of an electromagnet when current flows through it.
questions.explanation: The iron nail attracts the paper clips at its ends when current flows through the coil.

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used in loading furnaces with iron.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in loading furnaces with iron.

questions.statement: A weak electromagnet is obtained if the number of turns of the coil is increased.
questions.explanation: A weak electromagnet is obtained if turns are less. More turns make it stronger.

questions.statement: Electromagnetism deals with the magnetic effect of electric current.
questions.explanation: The branch of physics which deals with the magnetic effect of electric current is called electromagnetism.

questions.statement: For electromagnetic induction, relative motion between magnet and conductor is essential.
questions.explanation: Without relative motion, there is no change in magnetic flux and no induced current.

questions.statement: Soft iron has high retentivity which makes it ideal for electromagnets.
questions.explanation: Soft iron has low retentivity, which is why it loses magnetism quickly when current stops.

questions.statement: The plastic coating on copper wire is removed to make better insulation.
questions.explanation: Plastic coating is removed from wire ends to make electrical contact, not for insulation.

questions.statement: MRI machines use electromagnets to create images of body organs.
questions.explanation: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) uses powerful electromagnets for medical imaging.

questions.statement: Reversing current direction in an electromagnet reverses its poles.
questions.explanation: When current direction is reversed, the north and south poles of the electromagnet swap.

questions.statement: The hammer in an electric bell keeps striking due to the make-and-break mechanism.
questions.explanation: The make-and-break mechanism causes repeated hammer strikes as circuit alternately completes and breaks.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Permanent magnets can be switched off to release attracted objects.
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets cannot be switched off; electromagnets can be switched off to release loads.

questions.statement: If both magnet and conductor are stationary, induced current is maximum.
questions.explanation: If both are stationary, induced current is zero because there is no change in magnetic flux.

questions.statement: Copper wire is used in electromagnets because it is a good conductor.
questions.explanation: Copper is an excellent electrical conductor, making it ideal for electromagnet coils.

questions.statement: The gong in an electric bell is made of rubber for better sound.
questions.explanation: The gong is made of metal to produce a clear ringing sound.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: U-shaped electromagnets have both poles on the same side.
questions.explanation: The U-shape brings both poles close together on the same side.

questions.statement: Maglev trains use electromagnets for magnetic levitation.
questions.explanation: Maglev (magnetic levitation) trains float above tracks using electromagnetic forces.

questions.statement: The magnetic field of an electromagnet is strongest at the center of the core.
questions.explanation: The magnetic field is strongest at the poles of an electromagnet, not at the center.

questions.statement: Electromagnets can only attract iron and steel.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets attract all ferromagnetic materials including iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt.

questions.statement: The contact screw in an electric bell is made of plastic.
questions.explanation: The contact screw is made of metal to conduct electricity.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Doubling the current through an electromagnet doubles its strength.
questions.explanation: Strength is directly proportional to current, so doubling current doubles strength.

questions.statement: Steel is preferred over soft iron for making electromagnet cores.
questions.explanation: Soft iron is preferred because it loses magnetism quickly when current stops.

questions.statement: Telephone speakers use electromagnets to convert electrical signals to sound.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets in telephones convert electrical signals to sound and vice versa.

questions.statement: A fair test in science requires a control experiment.
questions.explanation: A fair test requires comparing with a control - testing with and without the variable.

questions.statement: When current stops, an electromagnet becomes a permanent magnet.
questions.explanation: When current stops, the soft iron core loses its magnetism completely.

questions.statement: Insulation on wire prevents short circuits between coil turns.
questions.explanation: Insulation prevents short circuits between adjacent turns, ensuring current flows through all turns.

questions.statement: Faster change in magnetic flux produces smaller induced current.
questions.explanation: Faster change in magnetic flux produces greater induced current.

questions.statement: Electric bells can operate on direct current from batteries.
questions.explanation: Most electric bells operate on direct current from batteries or transformers.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: The push button switch in an electric bell keeps the circuit always closed.
questions.explanation: The push button switch closes the circuit only when pressed.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Closely wound coils have fewer turns per unit length.
questions.explanation: Closely wound coils have more turns per unit length, increasing magnetic strength.

questions.statement: Electromagnets are used to record data on magnetic tapes.
questions.explanation: Audio and video recording equipment uses electromagnets to magnetize tape for data storage.

questions.statement: In scrap yards, electromagnets separate iron from non-magnetic waste.
questions.explanation: Electromagnets attract iron and steel, separating them from non-magnetic materials.

questions.statement: The polarity of an electromagnet depends on the type of core material used.
questions.explanation: Polarity depends on the direction of current flow, not the core material.

questions.statement: Paper clips fall off an electromagnet when the switch is turned off.
questions.explanation: When current stops, the electromagnet loses magnetism and releases the paper clips.

questions.statement: Batteries convert chemical energy to electrical energy.
questions.explanation: A battery converts chemical energy stored in it to electrical energy.

questions.statement: The armature in an electric bell is attracted to the gong.
questions.explanation: The armature is attracted to the electromagnet, not the gong.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Tape is used to secure wire ends to battery terminals in the electromagnet activity.
questions.explanation: Tape is used to connect and secure the wire ends to the battery terminals.

questions.statement: Single-pole magnets exist in nature.
questions.explanation: All magnets have two poles. Single-pole labelled magnets have one pole covered or hidden.

questions.statement: The induced current depends on the rate of change of magnetic flux.
questions.explanation: Greater rate of change in magnetic flux produces greater induced current.
